title: My daughter was issued a 1099C from Toyota in 2009 and never received it. Will the IRS reduce some penalties & interest for her?
question: She is a single parent, very low income, living right now on Temporary Disability because of a work injury. She also has no job to return to, as the business closed during her workers' comp claim.
question_tags: Small business taxes,Small business tax forms,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Work-related personal injuries,Business,Tax law
answers: Whether you receive a 1099 or not is not determinative as to whether this income should have been claimed. If your daughter had debt canceled it is income. However, there is an exception that my help your daughter. If she was insolvent (her debts exceeded her assets) at the time the debt was forgiven she can exclude the canceled debt to the extent she was insolvent. This is based on IRC section 108. The exclusion is claimed on Form 982. If she was not insolvent she may be able to file an offer in compromise. See a local tax professional to help prepare this if you are not familiar with the process.

She could try an offer in compromise but be aware there are a lot of forms to fill out, there is a filing fee and she must offer something to compromise the debt. Since the debt of $900 (and it is assumed this includes interest and penalty) is only somewhat greater than these costs and a deposit she may want to consider just paying it off via an installment agreeement (while attempting to get the penalty waived for reasonable cause) to avoid the aggravation and uncertaintly of the offer in compromise. By the way, very few of them are accepted from what statistics indicate.

The lack of notice of the 1099C could be due to the fact that she moved several times. The lenders send the forms to the last known address they have on file.

Did the daughter not know that the debt was being cancelled on the repossession?

The IRS could just write this off as uncollectible. Perhaps your daughter could complete the offer in compromise forms and request that the request that her offer be considered for "efficient tax administration"

Go to the IRS web site and read up on offers in compromise.

BW
